content.title: Subclavian Steal Syndrome
content.definition: Reversed vertebral artery blood flow due to proximal subclavian or innominate artery stenosis/occlusion, causing blood to be 'stolen' from the vertebrobasilar circulation to supply the arm during exercise. May cause posterior circulation symptoms (vertebrobasilar insufficiency) when the arm is exercised.

mechanism: Ipsilateral vertebral artery becomes low-resistance outflow
Blood flows retrograde down vertebral artery to arm
Arm exercise increases demand → more 'steal' from brain
pathophysiology.anatomic_requirements: Subclavian stenosis proximal to vertebral artery origin

hemodynamic_grades.partial: Alternating flow direction with cardiac cycle

epidemiology.laterality: Left sided 3x more common than right

subclavian_steal_syndrome.definition: Symptomatic steal with posterior circulation symptoms
subclavian_steal_syndrome.frequency: Minority of patients with steal phenomenon

duplex_ultrasound.reactive_hyperemia: Inflate BP cuff, release, observe steal

special_considerations.lima_graft: Treatment threshold lower due to coronary implications
special_considerations.takayasu: May need medical therapy, timing considerations

content.statement: Subclavian Steal Syndrome is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Upper-Extremity that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Subclavian Steal Syndrome helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Subclavian Steal Syndrome include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Subclavian Steal Syndrome.

learning_objectives: Differentiate subclavian steal phenomenon from syndrome
Recognize clinical presentation and trigger factors
Apply appropriate diagnostic and treatment algorithms
clinical_pearls: Most patients with steal phenomenon are ASYMPTOMATIC - don't overtreate
Left side is 3x more common than right (proximal left subclavian is more horizontal)
>20 mmHg BP difference between arms is a clue
Coronary subclavian steal in LIMA-LAD patients is a lower threshold for treatment
Arm exercise provokes posterior circulation symptoms - ask specifically
common_misconceptions: Misconception: All patients with reversed vertebral flow need treatment - Reality: Most are asymptomatic and only syndrome requires treatment
